results.title: Assam: where mighty Brahmaputra flows
results.brief_description: Assam is a land of rivers and mountains, famed for its natural beauty. Its industries are sericulture as a cottage industry; metal as a flourishing craft; teas as an important source of foreign exchange; the Digboi Oil Refinery, as the only one of its kind in India; and jute, a very vital product. This is an exotic insight into some of Assam’s cultural aspects by focussing on social behaviour and virtue. Also depicts the fine river, Brahmaputra.

results.title: Asphalt Lake
results.creator_credit: A. Frank Bundy and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: After giving examples of the everyday uses of asphalt for road-makling and roofing, this film shows the position of Pitch Lake at La Brea, Trinidad on a large-scale map. Details the work carried out at the lakeside, and in the refineries.

results.title: Askja on fire: volcanic eruption in Iceland 1961
results.brief_description: Shows the massive eruption of the volcano Askja in the central highlands of Iceland in 1961. Presents contrasting scenes of the glowing molten lava against a background of snow and ice. Narrated by Brian D. Holt. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Asian earth
results.brief_description: Documents the activities and provlems of a Hindu peasant family of the lower Ganges Valley. They are seen at work, play, and worship during the cycle of one year. In the narration, the mother of the family presents here explanation and interpretation. (Awards: First prize at Golden Reel Festival; Cleveland; Stamford; Illinois)

results.title: Asia Wise
results.creator_credit: John Honey, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Education Dept Tasmania
results.brief_description: In the diverse and complex countries of Asia today, it seems that the only unifying forces are both change and tradition. This video covers: Student protests in China; peasants in modern China; the new Cambodia; Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong; Japanese youth - an education for life and breaking the pattern of tradition; the depletion of Asian forest resources; Sado - the Japanese tea ceremony; Yum Cha - traditional Chinese tea and snacks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Honey, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Education Dept Tasmania

results.title: Ashputtle or the mother's ghost
results.creator_credit: Nag Vladermersky, Susi Allender, Australian Film Commission and Beastie Films
results.brief_description: Based on the original story by Angela Carter from a collection of short stories called “American ghosts and old world wonders”, this is an adaptation of what is most popularly known as the tale of Cinderella. Using cut-out animation and filmed on 35mm, Ashputtle tells the story of a mother who comes back from the grave to help her mistreated daughter. She enlists the help of a cow, a cat and a bird to restore her daughter’s beauty and set the world right so that she might rest in peace. Voice-over by Linda Gibson and music by Amelia Barden.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nag Vladermersky, Susi Allender, Australian Film Commission and Beastie Films

results.title: Ascot: a race against time
results.creator_credit: James Carr, Wimpey Organization and World Wide
results.brief_description: The building of the new Queen Elizabeth II Grandstand at Ascot in record time, and an account of the work which was involved. Ten months was the scheduled time allowed for the builders to replace the old Grand Tier - ten months of close co-operation between client, architect, engineer and construction team. Great use of archival footage giving a sense of history and interesting juxtaposition between the models of the new Ascot and its actual construction.

results.title: As is
results.creator_credit: Michael Lindsay-Hogg, Iris Merlis, Brandman Productions and Interchange Television Group
results.brief_description: Based on a play by William M. Hoffman, this made for television feature length film was originally produced for Broadway by The Circle Repertory Company and The Glines. Reflective, confronting, compassionate, and experimental in treatment and language “As is” deals up-front with the issue of AIDS in its early days, documenting the different phases from all angles, from the victim through to the lover, the friends, the family and the health carers. Through a montage of scenes, multi-layered, past and present, we witness the story of Rich (Robert Carradine), a Manhattan-based writer who discovers he has a pre-AIDS condition, subsequently finding himself being ostracised by one and all. Alienated and surrounded by fear and paranoia Rich has to mentally come to terms with AIDS and the ignorance which exists amongst the general population, including the medical fraternity, about this new disease. His friend and ex-lover Saul (Jonathan Hadary) is there to support Rich through the emotional stages of fear, anger, denial, cynicism, death vs the will to live, and finally, acceptance. Colleen Dewhurst is outstanding as the hospice worker who through her monologues to the camera tells us what it’s like caring for AIDS patients, her emotional attachments and her anger and frustration with this disease called AIDS. Although acted and directed in a theatrical style, “As is” still is an exceptional film, informative and compassionate, and particularly interesting from an historical viewpoint. Cast also includes Joanna Miles, Allan Scarfe.
